summary: Directed evolution techniques are used to improve biocatalyst properties such as enantioselectivity and substrate specificity, often outperforming rational design methods.
key_claims: Enzymes can be evolved for improved enantioselectivity through directed evolution, with an example showing a 40-fold increase in ee from 2% to 81%.
Directed evolution is effective for tuning substrate specificity, as demonstrated by the five orders of magnitude increase in activity towards valine and 2-oxovaline.
